issue.title: `Buffer is not defined` when using WebGL runtime

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
On line 11711 of ort.js (v1.9.0) `Buffer.from(...)` is called, but `Buffer` is not defined:

```js
if (attr instanceof onnx_proto_1.onnx.AttributeProto) {
    var utf8String = value;
    return Buffer.from(utf8String.buffer, utf8String.byteOffset, utf8String.byteLength).toString();
}
```

I thought that this `Buffer` might have been a Node.js polyfill, but I tried importing the [feross/buffer](https://josephrocca.github.io/anime-gan-v2-web/onnx.html) polyfill and it didn't work - seems that Node's `Buffer.from` only takes 2 arguments.

**Urgency**
Not urgent

**System information**
- ONNX Runtime Version: https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/onnxruntime-web@1.9.0/dist/ort.js
- Tested on Firefox 94 and Chrome 95 (latest versions)

**To Reproduce**
Visit this page: https://josephrocca.github.io/anime-gan-v2-web/onnx.html (switch to the WebGL runtime and then click "start")

The github repo is here: https://github.com/josephrocca/anime-gan-v2-web

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1167575/141681620-3803900a-6791-4ea6-8f23-bc4ce0764ace.png)

**Additional context**
It works fine with the wasm runtime. The [original model](https://github.com/josephrocca/anime-gan-v2-web/blob/main/anime-gan-v2.onnx) used some int64 values (and the WebGL backend [does not support int64](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9724)) so I converted it to int32 using [this script](https://github.com/aadhithya/onnx-typecast). That said, I doubt this is relevant. Seems more likely to just be a bundling issue, or something like that.

body: One workaround might be to use this script to typecast to int32, since int64 seems to often be unnecessary: https://github.com/aadhithya/onnx-typecast I'm in the process of testing this but am held up by a [different bug](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9757).

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.

I updated [the example](https://josephrocca.github.io/anime-gan-v2-web/onnx.html) to v1.11.0 and the webgl runtime still doesn't support `int64`, so I think this should remain open.

I wonder if it'd be easier to fulfill the needs of most users by just having an option/setting to automatically cast `int64` to `int32`? I think in most cases when trying to get a pre-trained model working on the web, the model uses `int64` not because it actually requires 64 bits, but because the model author just uses that as the default int.

issue.title: [js/web] WebGPU backend

labels.name: platform:web
labels.description: issues related to ONNX Runtime web; typically submitted using template

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
CPU/Wasm inference is slow on larger models. If a device has a GPU and the model is large, then using the CPU is not a good choice. The WebGL runtime has three problems:

1. It is much harder to get it working due to op and data-type support issues. Examples: [1](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/9724), [2](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/10031)
2. It is likely to be significantly slower than WebGPU.
3. In my testing it is often unstable and can either throw an error that requires refreshing the tab to fix, or breaks WebGL across all tabs (requiring a browser restart) or even freezes my whole laptop. That said, this may just be specific to Ubuntu, or even my specific OS/hardware combination - I'm not sure. I'm guessing that in general it has to do with high memory usage.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
By far the most important requirement is that there is very strong op support, just like the Wasm backend. The broad op support is what sets ORT Web (Wasm backend) apart from tfjs, and some other web runtimes.

I still bump into ORT Web Wasm op support problems sometimes, but far less often than with other runtimes. I'm guessing this is due to the fact that the ops can be compiled from their C++/C/etc code rather than having to be re-written specifically for the web. I hope that the WebGPU backend would be able to do something similar, because otherwise I fear that lack of op support would make it far less useful. I am rarely able to get the WebGL backend working with my models because of op and data type support issues.

Might it be possible to set up some sort of conversion pipeline (perhaps via SPIR-V) to WGSL using [Naga](https://github.com/gfx-rs/naga) and similar tools? This is beyond my pay grade, so I'm just guessing here.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Seems like there are people already working on this: https://github.com/webonnx/wonnx But it is unfortunately not stable or op/feature-complete.

**Additional context**
WebGPU is behind a flag in Chrome, and is expected to ship by default in Chrome this year or early next year. It might be useful to start working on this now so that the ORT Web team can perhaps [provide feedback](https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/issues) on the WebGPU spec while there's an opportunity to make changes. The earlier the feedback, the easier it is to make changes to the spec which could be critical for getting maximum ML performance out of WebGPU.
